content:
Nice clash, few small suggestions:

"We simply ignore that some constants in some cases act as vocals. Eg. 'H' in hour and 'Y' in my, by, gym or bicycle."
constants -> consonants
vocals -> vowels

The handling of case is a bit tricky since 'Abobcoc' could decrypt to 'Abc' or 'ABC' or 'ABc' or 'AbC'. It's more clear in the encryption than the decryption. This was a little bit confusing in-clash, so could perhaps be clarified.

Also, there's no test cases that actually ensure that you don't reduce *o* patterns where * is a vowel or other non-consonant character. e.g. you could have "Rorioi" -> "Rioi" and not "Ri". Currently you can just replace any (.)o\1 pattern with \1 and not worry about making sure the '.' is a consonant ([^aeiou\d_\W]). I kind of like that this isn't tested, as it made it easier in Shortest mode, but ideally you would want to test it otherwise all the explanation about consonants and vowels is irrelevant.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I think the exercise is interesting.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice one.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I think it's solvable in the given time
Quite easy to solve by a simple regex...
I don't understand the meaning of the sentence "We ignore the odd behavior of 'Y', 'W', and other odd vocal corner cases for simplicity." In fact, you're assuming that 'Y' is a vowel...
Good puzzle. I think that it's only fitted for speed mod.

Constraint section
* Please change "len" to "length". We should use English and try to avoid any programming keyword in the statement.
* Please change "vocal" to "vowel".
* The upper limits are overstated, especially for length of s. The stub generator code suggests that each string is at most 256 characters long, so use that as a guide to change the second upper limit.
* The first one may also be changed to 10 (upper limits are usually stated in powers of 2 or 10).
* You may use the {{constant}} syntax for a, z, A, Z and the puntuations.
* The quotation marks around the punctuations may also be removed, but then the space character has to be stated like this: {{space}}.
* Suggest to move the last constraint to Goal section as it is more of an explanation of the rules.

Goal section
* For completeness, please add that a consonant is any letter which is not a vowel.
* Please fix the spelling: "Discaliner" => "Disclaimer".

Input section
* Please add line numbers, e.g. <<Line 1:>> and <<Next [[n]] lines:>>.


Thanks.

Thanks a lot for the feedback.
I think that got most of it covered.

Thanks.
Personally, I think it is a good CodeGolf (short mode) challenge. Not easy to make very short - but yet a fair challenge.

Vowels in English is ambiguous - which especially is confusing to no non-native English speakers. 
Letters like 'Y', 'W' and 'H' in some cases behave like vowels but are formally not considered vowels. Eg. in 'try' 'Y' is a vowel while in beyond it's a consonant. It an hour, but a horse. ect.

Absolutely correct - and that approach might do your well in shortest mode.
I often wonder why we have so few RegEx challenges.
Thanks - it hopefully should be. I often find more difficult problems in clash of code.
I would be much clearer if you stated that Y must be considered as a vowel (thus is not followed by "oy"). ;)

I think just removing the note will make things clear by just stating that:
Vowels in English are the letters 'A', 'E', 'I', 'O', and 'U'. A consonant is any letter that is not a vowel.

This is about solving the puzzle of the encoding - not the oddness of the English language.

The real-life example that I build this challenge on is phonetical focused. 
While a simplified coded version needs to be focused on the letters - not the sounds and phonology. 
Se: https://www.grammar-monster.com/glossary/vowels.htm - the first video.
